name: Mercury
fact1: Temperatures on Mercury range from -173C (-280F) at night to 427C (800F) during the day due to its lack of atmosphere.
fact2: Mercury is the closest planet to the Sun, with an average distance of about 58 million kilometres (36 million miles). Despite this, it isn't the hottest planet.

name: Venus
fact1: Venus rotates in the opposite direction to most planets, meaning the Sun rises in the west and sets in the east.
fact2: Venus has the hottest surface in the solar system, with temperatures around 475C (900F), caused by its thick atmosphere of carbon dioxide.

name: Earth
fact1: Earth's crust is divided into tectonic plates that move and interact, causing earthquakes, volcanic activity, and mountain formation.
fact2: Earth is the only planet known to support life, thanks to its liquid water, breathable atmosphere, and stable climate.

name: Mars
fact1: Olympus Mons on Mars is the tallest volcano in the solar system, standing about 22 kilometres (13.6 miles) high.
fact2: Mars gets its red colour from iron oxide (rust) on its surface.

name: Jupiter
fact1: It has a giant storm called the Great Red Spot, which has been raging for at least 400 years and is larger than Earth.
fact2: Jupiter is the largest planet in the solar system, with a diameter of about 139,820 kilometres (86,881 miles).

name: Saturn
fact1: Saturn is so light for its size that it would float in water (if there were a body of water large enough!).
fact2: Saturn is famous for its stunning ring system, made of ice and rock particles ranging in size from grains to house-sized chunks.

name: Uranus
fact1: Its blue-green colour comes from methane in its atmosphere, which absorbs red light.
fact2: Uranus rotates on its side, with an axial tilt of 98 degrees, making its seasons extreme.

name: Neptune
fact1: Similar to Jupiter's Great Red Spot, Neptune has a massive storm called the Great Dark Spot, which was first observed in 1989.
fact2: Neptune has the fastest winds in the solar system, reaching speeds of up to 2,100 kilometres per hour (1,300 miles per hour).
